title: How to Cure Ham

steps.headline: Mix 2 pounds (0.9 kg) of non-iodized salt and 1 pound (0.4 kg) of white or brown sugar in a bowl.
steps.description: The sugar will offset the salty flavor.

steps.headline: Add approximately 1 ounce (28 g) of saltpeter to help preserve the curing flavor.
steps.description: Blend the saltpeter, salt, and sugar.

steps.headline: Combine 8 tablespoons (118 ml) of brown sugar, 2 cups (1.8 metric cups) of salt, 2 tablespoons (29 ml) of red pepper, 4 tablespoons (59 ml) of black pepper and 1/2 teaspoon (2.4 ml) of saltpeter if you want to use an alternative recipe.
steps.description: Mix all the ingredients before applying them to the ham.

methods.name: Add the Curing Mix to the Ham

steps.headline: Open the hock-end portion of the ham.
steps.description: Add at least 3 tablespoons (44 ml) of curing mix inside the ham to cover the middle joint. Applying the cure inside the ham prevents the bone from spoiling.

steps.headline: Cover the skin of the ham with the curing mix, then cover the lean cuts of the ham.
Place the cured ham in wrapping paper.
steps.description: Cover the wrapping paper tightly to keep the cure mixture on the ham.

steps.headline: Put the wrapped, cured ham into a stockinette bag, and then hang it in a well-ventilated room.
steps.description: Let the ham cure 2.5 to 3 days per pound of ham. Depending on the size, ham needs up to 40 days of cold weather for curing to prevent it from spoiling.

methods.name: Complete the Curing Process and Age the Ham

steps.headline: After 3 days of curing, remove the wrapping paper from the ham.
steps.description: Remove any mold and excess curing mix from the ham by using a cloth and some vinegar.

steps.headline: Blot the ham dry with the cloth, and cover it with vegetable oil, which will keep mold growth at bay.
steps.description: The curing process should completely cure the ham by the beginning of April.

steps.headline: Re-wrap the ham to prepare it for aging.
steps.description: Place it in a stockinette and let it hang in the same well-ventilated area where you cured it. Age the ham for 3 to 6 months so it achieves more flavor.
